Inauguration Day 2017, Donald Trump Sworn In As 45th President Of The United States Donald Trump has completed an unlikely journey from real estate mogul to the 45th president of the United States.
In Inaugural Address, Trump Decries 'Carnage' And Promises 'America First'

NPRPolitics

Politics

In Inaugural Address, Trump Decries 'Carnage' And Promises 'America First'

January 20, 201712:01 PM ET

Carrie Johnson

Twitter
Enlarge this image

Donald Trump arrives at his inauguration at the Capitol. Doug Mills/Pool/Getty Images hide caption

toggle caption
Doug Mills/Pool/Getty Images

Donald Trump arrives at his inauguration at the Capitol.

Doug Mills/Pool/Getty Images

A newly inaugurated Donald J. Trump delivered a fiercely populist and often dark address, promising to transfer power in Washington from political elites to the people and vowing to put "America first."

Surrounded by members of Congress and the Supreme Court, the nation's 45th president repeated themes from his historic and divisive campaign message, describing children in poverty, schools in crisis and streets pocked with crime and "carnage."

Politics

President Trump's Inaugural Address, Annotated

"For too long, a small group in our nation's capital has reaped the rewards of government while the people have borne the cost," Trump said. "Washington flourished but the people did not share in its wealth. The establishment protected itself."

(Left) Military personnel salute during the National Anthem at the start of the inauguration, as spectators try to catch a view of the stage from the Mall. Gabriella Demczuk for NPR hide caption

toggle caption
Gabriella Demczuk for NPR

In his 16-minute remarks, he criticized an educational system "flush with cash" that fails to fulfill its mission to students. He lamented factories left to rust while jobs flowed overseas. And he decried crime and gang violence, despite reports from the FBI and criminologists that the U.S. crime rate remains near historic lows.

"This American carnage stops right here and stops right now," Trump said, amid cheers from the crowd.

Credit: NPR

Moments earlier, with his hand on Bibles once used by Abraham Lincoln and his own family, Trump pledged to "preserve, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States," completing an unlikely trajectory from real-estate mogul to the nation's 45th president.

Politics

Live Coverage: Donald Trump's Presidential Inauguration

A crowd that stretched along the National Mall assembled under gray Washington skies to witness the ceremony. So did nearly every living former president, from Jimmy Carter and George W. Bush to Bill Clinton and his wife, Hillary, who was defeated by Trump last November after a costly and bitter campaign.

Afterward, dozens of dignitaries walked through light rain into the Capitol for a three-course lunch program emceed by Missouri Republican Sen. Roy Blunt. The menu included Maine lobster and Gulf shrimp with saffron sauce and peanut crumble, Angus beef with dark chocolate sauce and potato gratin, and chocolate souffle with cherry vanilla ice cream.

(Left) A woman covers herself from the rain as she waits for the start of the inauguration on the National Mall. (Center) A couple, in complementary scarves, watch as the crowd fills in. (Right) A child covers herself from the rain while laying on the ground at the Mall. Gabriella Demczuk for NPR hide caption

toggle caption
Gabriella Demczuk for NPR

Trump and his vice president, former Indiana Gov. Mike Pence, presided over the parade, which stretched a little under 2 miles from the U.S. Capitol to the White House. School marching bands, the Boy Scouts, veterans groups and 8,000 members of the military participated.

Politics

Donald Trump Has Plans To Hit The Ground Running. Here's What He Wants To Do

Also lining that route: Protesters representing 99 different groups. In sporadic exchanges at security check points across downtown Washington, protesters shouted: "No Trump! No KKK! No fascist USA!" Others carried signs with such slogans as "Fake 45."

  • Protests began in the early morning hours, with attempts to block entrances to the National Mall and parade route.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • People walk past a "Homeless Lives Matter" mural on D street in the early morning hours.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • Police on horses surveyed the grounds as spectators gathered before the start of the inauguration events.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • A spectator sports Trump-themed socks near the National Mall.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • People on the street chant as part of a peaceful protest during the inauguration.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • Bicyclists block K Street near McPherson Square, posing for photos in the street.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • A protestor climbs a tree in Franklin Square to get a better view of a protest action happening nearby.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • A helicopter flies by as smoke rises from a trash fire on K Street, between 13th and 14th Streets, near Franklin Square.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • Spectators take photographs of a trash fire started by protesters on K Street.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • A protestor, who did not want to be named, poses for a portrait to show tear streaks on his face after he was hit with pepper spray.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • People stand on a bus stop that was spray-painted with the words "We the People" during the protest.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • The National Guard makes a line in front of protesters at the intersection of K Street and 14th Street Northwest.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • People run from smoke and fire that billows from near Franklin Square, where a limo was set on fire.
    Claire Harbage/NPR
  • A police officer takes a break to eat a snack while protestors remain peacefully detained in the background.
    Claire Harbage/NPR

1 of 14

But, so far, skirmishes appeared to be mostly free from violence. Not far from the White House, several hundred protesters clad in black ran through the streets, breaking windows and knocking over trash cans. Police fired pepper spray to subdue demonstrators. The Metropolitan Police Department reported at least 95 arrests, mostly on charges of rioting.

Preparations for the event had been under way for months. Around 28,000 officers are on hand to provide security for the event, including Secret Service, FBI agents, the Coast Guard, police departments and nearly 8,000 National Guard troops. Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson said authorities had "no specific, credible threat" directed at the proceedings.

(Left) A Capitol Hill police officer gets help with his riot gear early on the morning of the inauguration of Donald J. Trump. (Center) A vendor sells Trump merchandise at the entrance to the National Mall. (Right) Capitol Hill police line up in riot gear in the early morning hours. Gabriella Demczuk for NPR hide caption

toggle caption
Gabriella Demczuk for NPR

Meanwhile, at the White House, household crews are furiously preparing the mansion for its new occupants. Earlier in the day, camera crews spotted President Obama making one last visit to the Oval Office, slipping a letter in the desk drawer for his successor.

Politics

Donald Trump's Been Saying The Same Thing For 30 Years

Staff members at the residence presented the Obamas with two flags: one that welcomed them to the White House eight years ago; another that flew over the building Friday morning, on their last day there. The Obama family headed to Palm Springs, California, Friday for a vacation.

Enlarge this image

President Trump waves as he walks with first lady Melania Trump during the inauguration parade on Pennsylvania Avenue on Friday. Evan Vucci/AP hide caption

toggle caption
Evan Vucci/AP

President Trump waves as he walks with first lady Melania Trump during the inauguration parade on Pennsylvania Avenue on Friday.

Evan Vucci/AP

The formal hand-off of power is now complete, as the Trump administration only begins to come into focus. Trump, who has had no experience in elective office, now controls a vast federal bureaucracy, including national security, international diplomacy, the economy, the environment and the justice system. He's painted his governing agenda in broad strokes, promising to "Make America Great Again" by bringing jobs back to the U.S. and deliver a tough message on the international stage.

His remarks from the inaugural platform harked back to his campaign speeches: "We will bring back our jobs. We will bring back our borders. We will bring back our wealth and we will bring back our dreams."

President Trump is joined by congressional leaders and his family as he formally signs his cabinet nominations into law, in the President's Room of the Senate. J. Scott Applewhite/Pool/Getty Images hide caption

toggle caption
J. Scott Applewhite/Pool/Getty Images

Trump went on to blast "empty talk" by politicians of the past. "Now arrives the hour of action," he said.

Flanked by his extended family, his vice president, and congressional leaders, Trump took his first actions: signing papers for his cabinet nominees and proclaiming a national day of patriotism.

Trash litters the National Mall at the end of the inauguration event. Gabriella Demczuk for NPR hide caption

toggle caption
Gabriella Demczuk for NPR

  • White House
  • Republicans

In Inaugural Address, Trump Decries 'Carnage' And Promises 'America First'

Enlarge this image toggle caption Doug Mills/Pool/Getty Images Doug Mills/Pool/Getty Images

A newly inaugurated Donald J. Trump delivered a fiercely populist and often dark address, promising to transfer power in Washington from political elites to the people and vowing to put "America first."

toggle caption Gabriella Demczuk for NPR

In his 16-minute remarks, he criticized an educational system "flush with cash" that fails to fulfill its mission to students. He lamented factories left to rust while jobs flowed overseas. And he decried crime and gang violence, despite reports from the FBI and criminologists that the U.S. crime rate remains near historic lows.

The menu included Maine lobster and Gulf shrimp with saffron sauce and peanut crumble, Angus beef with dark chocolate sauce and potato gratin, and chocolate souffle with cherry vanilla ice cream.
